byline.original: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The plan had been carefully constructed for weeks. When the doctors looked at Earvin Johnson's surgical left knee and decided he could return to the Los Angeles Lakers Feb. 20, Jerry Buss, who owns Johnson's smile and his knee, looked at the schedule and decided to wait another seven days. He waited because, on the Laker calendar, the box for Feb. 27 was in yellow, which means a home game. Inside the box, Buss saw the letters ''N.J.'' The New Jersey Nets. A sellout. A happening. A breeze. At the end of an evening that Buss called semipainful, the Lakers' owner laughed nervously. ''It didn't exactly work out that way,'' he said. The plan did not include the fact that, after missing 45 games, or more than half a season, Magic Johnson would have to help the Lakers win a game last night.

headline.main: Stamps; INTERPEX SHOW WILL FEATURE SPACE SHUTTLE EXHIBIT; by Samuel A.Tower

results.snippet: Like the first robin, the advent of INTERPEX, arriving regularly at its destined time, heralds an end to winter's chill and the beginning of an extended weekend to enjoy stamps.   This year, INTERPEX heralds even more: the first great undertaking...
results.lead_paragraph: Like the first robin, the advent of INTERPEX, arriving regularly at its destined time, heralds an end to winter's chill and the beginning of an extended weekend to enjoy stamps. This year, INTERPEX heralds even more: the first great undertaking of man in space since the landings on the moon. The 1981 stamp show is built around the imminently scheduled flight of the Space Shuttle - or Space Transportation System, as the whole assemblage of the versatile space freighter is known. The United States has scheduled for next month a set of eight Space Achievement stamps, keyed to the shuttle, a revolutionary spacecraft that makes all others obsolete and is basic to future developments in space. Simulated exhibits of the Space Shuttle, its elements and its voyage -realistic and often close to actual size - have been provided by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and other Federal agencies. The exhibits are described as being so dramatic that they will even make enthusiastic stamp collectors stop to look while scurrying to see the dealers' booths.

headline.main: AN ASTRONAUT PREDICTS SHORT SHUTTLE FLIGHT

results.snippet: Declaring that the space shuttle in time will ''absolutely revolutionize the way we do business on earth,'' the astronaut who is scheduled to command the first such craft on its maiden voyage early next month said yesterday that he, his co-pilot...
results.lead_paragraph: Declaring that the space shuttle in time will ''absolutely revolutionize the way we do business on earth,'' the astronaut who is scheduled to command the first such craft on its maiden voyage early next month said yesterday that he, his co-pilot and the ship, named Columbia, were at long last ''just about ready to go.'' But in the two astronauts' last formal appearance before the scheduled launching of Columbia, one of them predicted that the flight likely would not go its scheduled distance of 36 revolutions of the earth in 54 1/2 hours. ''I think the odds, with the way we've designed the mission right now, are that we'll probably come home early,'' said Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, who will be making his first flight into space. The commander of the flight is John W. Young, a veteran astronaut who has been into space four times and walked on the moon once. They are scheduled to be launched from Cape Canaveral early in the week of April 5 and to glide to a controlled landing, airplane-style, at Edwards Air Force Base in California later that same week.

results.snippet: The Soviet Union sent aloft a manned capsule Soyuz T-4, carrying two astronauts, toward a linkup with the orbiting Salyut 6 space station, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, announced today.   Tass identified the astronauts as Col. Vladimir...
results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union sent aloft a manned capsule Soyuz T-4, carrying two astronauts, toward a linkup with the orbiting Salyut 6 space station, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, announced today. Tass identified the astronauts as Col. Vladimir Kovalyonok, the flight commander, and Viktor Savinykh, the flight engineer.

headline.main: AMID THE HIGH DRAMA OF THE SHUTTLE, A MECHANIC PLAYS A PAINSTAKING ROLE

results.snippet: hour shift, he empties his pockets, pulls a tight, knitted sleeve over his wrist watch, and runs a bandage lashed around his wrist through the wedding ring on his finger. He then rides an elevator high above the windswept flats of Cape Kennedy and...
results.lead_paragraph: hour shift, he empties his pockets, pulls a tight, knitted sleeve over his wrist watch, and runs a bandage lashed around his wrist through the wedding ring on his finger. He then rides an elevator high above the windswept flats of Cape Kennedy and goes to work on the space shuttle Columbia. If Mr. Blackard or his co-workers were to drop so much as a coin from their perches hundreds of feet high, it could result in devastating damage to the $9 billion shuttle. Tethering loose objects is just one of the innumerable precautions that have become second nature for the team. Driving 30 miles to work from his home in Geneva, Fla., Mr. Blackard, wearing a sport shirt and visored cap, is indistinguishable from other rush-hour commuters or vacationers. But after showing his badge at various checkpoints inside the vast space center, he becomes one of 18,000 men and women who are racing the clock to complete preparations for the maiden flight of the shuttle, which is scheduled for the week of April 6. His employer, Martin Marietta Aerospace Corporation, built the shuttle's huge external fuel tank, and flaws in the tank must be repaired quickly if the shuttle is to lift off next month.

headline.main: THE MORNING LINE; by William Safire

results.snippet: Now that Ronald Reagan has been President for all of two months, it is time to start asking, "Who's next?"   Among the Democrats, the old-face candidates will assiduously avoid the mistakes of their last campaigns. Accordingly, friends of Senator...
results.lead_paragraph: Now that Ronald Reagan has been President for all of two months, it is time to start asking, "Who's next?" Among the Democrats, the old-face candidates will assiduously avoid the mistakes of their last campaigns. Accordingly, friends of Senator Edward Kennedy (who in the year 2,000 will be as old as Ronald Reagan is today) are sending signals that he intends to be out of the starting gate early. He is sure to be better prepared for his formal opening interview with the highest-rated anchorman (who will by then be known as Uncle Roger).

headline.main: RUSSIAN AND MONGOLIAN ASTRONAUTS JOIN UP

results.snippet: A veteran Soviet astronaut and his Mongolian copilot maneuvered their Soyuz-39 spacecraft into a complex double docking late today with an orbiting Russian space station 200 miles above the earth.   As the docking was completed, 30 hours after...
results.lead_paragraph: A veteran Soviet astronaut and his Mongolian copilot maneuvered their Soyuz-39 spacecraft into a complex double docking late today with an orbiting Russian space station 200 miles above the earth. As the docking was completed, 30 hours after takeoff, Soviet television beamed an image of them bobbing weightlessly into the space lab Salyut-6 to join two others who had been orbiting aboard the station since the March 12 docking of their own capsule, Soyuz T-4.

results.snippet: EVEN at the moment they are bought, those cans of ground, dried spices that most of us keep on racks in the kitchen do not have the strength or the advantages of freshly ground spice. As time passes they lose what little they have going for them,...
results.lead_paragraph: EVEN at the moment they are bought, those cans of ground, dried spices that most of us keep on racks in the kitchen do not have the strength or the advantages of freshly ground spice. As time passes they lose what little they have going for them, making them worse than useless. The result is disappointment when a dish simply lacks the punch it is supposed to have.

headline.kicker: PRIVATE INC. IN THE PUBLIC PEN

results.snippet: As the Administration transforms ''high-powered business executives'' into ''highly placed Government officials,'' I recall my own impression that the only similar experience must be that of an astronaut who leaves home to operate weightless in...
results.lead_paragraph: As the Administration transforms ''high-powered business executives'' into ''highly placed Government officials,'' I recall my own impression that the only similar experience must be that of an astronaut who leaves home to operate weightless in space: The view is dazzling, but new forces are at play and nothing works the way it used to. As corporate managers become Government leaders, nowhere is the gravity of their change greater than in their new relationship with, and responsibility to, the news media. Yet media relationships are rarely mentioned in their briefing books, and their attitudes are perhaps irreparably warped by the often-stated (and overstated) warning that the Washington press corps is predatory, or worse. I recall one lawyer-turned-staffer brightly alerting an official heading for a news conference that ''the alligators are waiting.''
